description:
Amphilophus citrinellus, commonly known as the Midas cichlid, is a species of cichlid fish native to several large lakes in Nicaragua, including Lake Managua and Lake Nicaragua. This species is known for its unique and diverse coloration, ranging from golden-yellow to dark brown or black.

The Midas cichlid is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 30 centimeters (12 inches). It has a deep, laterally compressed body and a large, protruding mouth with strong jaws. The fish's distinctive feature is the presence of a prominent hump on the forehead, which becomes more pronounced as the fish matures.

Amphilophus citrinellus is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of prey, including aquatic plants, small invertebrates, and even other small fish. It is known for its aggressive territorial behavior, particularly during breeding and spawning periods, when the fish will fiercely defend their nesting sites.

This species is of significant ecological importance in its native habitat, serving as a key component of the lake's food web. It is also widely kept in the aquarium trade, where it is prized for its vibrant coloration and unique appearance.
